awd_titl_txt: Cultivating active learners by enabling instructors to monitor and enhance student buy-in and utilization of research-based instructional strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore ways to improve student buy-in and utilization of research-based instructional strategies (RBIS) that have been demonstrated to improve student learning and persistence across science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Over the past decades, the federal government has made substantial investments in the design, development, implementation, and evaluation of RBIS. These investments have resulted in increasingly greater implementation in classrooms across the country. However, many faculty have noted that they encounter student resistance when using RBIS.  The PI team from UNL is developing a means by which instructors can monitor and improve student engagement in and use of RBIS. Because of the widespread appeal and demonstrated impact on student learning of RBIS that serve in particular as formative assessments (FAs) (e.g., Just-in-Time Teaching, Peer Instruction), the PI team is focusing on this subset of RBIS. 

The project goals reflect a comprehensive set of development, research, and dissemination efforts designed to provide instructors with a customizable instrument and support model to optimize student engagement with FAs.  To achieve these goals, the PI team is developing a closed-ended Formative Assessment Buy-in and Utilization Survey (FABUS) to gauge how students perceive and interact with particular FA activities.  To broaden the impact of the project, they also are administering the FABUS at multiple institutions and conducting research to determine the relationships between buy-in, utilization, and learning related to various FA methods. Finally, they are creating a model for how a local community of instructors can use FABUS to identify issues, guide changes, and assess whether course alterations improve student learning through engagement in and utilization of FAs.  The instruments developed and the knowledge gained through this project have the potential to improve student STEM learning in classrooms across the nation, as instructors use these tools to promote student use of RBIS.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past decades, national agencies have made widespread efforts to promote the use of research-based teaching practices, such as formative assessments (FAs), as a way to improve student learning and persistence across STEM disciplines. While FAs have seen broad use in undergraduate STEM courses, their incorporation has been accompanied by significant challenges. In particular, FA implementation has been met with perceptions of student resistance, and it remains unclear whether students engage with FAs in a manner that maximizes learning. Student buy-in and utilization thus represent critical factors that potentially limit the adoption and efficacy of FAs.

The long-term goal of this project was to develop a means for instructors to monitor and improve student buy-in and utilization of FA activities. The project completed its three objectives aimed at providing instructors with an adaptable instrument and support model to optimize student FA engagement.

1) Develop the Formative Assessment Buy-in and Utilization Survey (FABUS) to gauge how students perceive and interact with particular FA activities.

2) Administer FABUS at multiple institutions and conduct research to determine the relationships between buy-in, utilization, and learning.

3) Establish a statewide community of instructors that use FABUS to identify issues, guide changes, and assess whether course alterations improve buy-in and utilization.

 

Intellectual Merit

This project followed a multi-pronged approach to help instructors improve student learning. FABUS was structured around a theoretical framework that sought to explain how FA characteristics ultimately affect student engagement and learning. FABUS has 12 sub-categories (eight related to student buy-in and four related to student utilization), and each sub-category includes four items with seven-point Likert-style response scales. The final version of FABUS was administered to over 5500 students in 71 courses at 11 institutions, including research-intensive institutions, regional universities, small liberal arts colleges, and community colleges. The FAs used in these courses represent a wide variety of in-class and out-of-class activity types. Confirmatory factor analysis revealed that the subcategories help explain variation in student responses and that all items adequately load onto their respective factors. Reliability analysis showed that all 12 sub-categories have acceptable internal reliabilities. Statistical models provided several key insights: (1) higher buy-in toward FAs predicted better utilization behaviors, (2) deeper utilization behaviors significantly predicted higher exam performance, (3) the connection between buy-in and exam performance was driven by effects of buy-in on utilization behaviors, which in turn affect performance.

 

Broader Impacts

The FABUS instrument provides a mechanism that can be used broadly to monitor and improve student FA buy-in and utilization. To structure faculty reflections around FABUS, three different meetings were held with 37 total faculty participants from 7 different institutions who had administered this instrument to their students. These faculty discussed their student feedback, shared ideas for addressing student concerns, and committed to implementing changes in their ensuing courses. Findings from follow up student surveys indicated that faculty saw increased, decreased, or no change in student engagement, which suggests that additional support and guidance may be needed to achieve consistent benefits. The research associated with this project provides important evidence regarding the impact of student buy-in and utilization on FA-related learning, and the FABUS instrument supports the continued adoption of research-based teaching practices by highlighting potential ways in which instructors might improve student engagement. Meetings among faculty have helped establish a local network of biology instructors committed to undergraduate education. Research results were disseminated to the broader community through two published manuscripts, two manuscripts near submission, and 43 public presentations. This project helped develop important human resources in discipline-based education research, including faculty, postdoctoral research assistants, graduate students, and undergraduate students.
